But as fact, slavery didn’t end with either Lincoln’s Proclamation on January 1, 1863 or General Grainer’s Army Order No. 3 for a part of Texas on June 19, 1865. 
https://t.co/de7BCseTap

1467958951094464518.text: It was, and remains, that only upon amending the US Constitution on Dec. 6, 1865 was slavery abolished in this country.  To be sure, a National Holiday to celebrate the end of slavery in America is a welcomed event regardless of the day chosen to do it.

1467958949970333699.text:
Today marks 156 years since the abolishment of slavery in America by the ratification of the 13th Amendment,
While we celebrate Juneteenth as a National Holiday, it is undisputed that nothing happened on that day to end slavery.

If you or someone you know is struggling or in crisis, you are not alone.

Call 1-800-273-8255 to reach the National Suicide Prevention lifeline. They provide confidential, 24-hour support and resources for you or your loved ones.

Hug the ones you care about, everyone.
